ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Amy and Bill are gems- we are so lucky to have them at FES. Incredibly knowledgeable, thoughtful teachers, open and humble, encouraging and challenging at the same time. Don't miss out on their expertise, mentorship, and incredible life experience!
I thought this class was super valuable! Really for any topic, breaking it down and being able to think about conservation issues from a variety of perspectives was very useful.
Yes

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Amy and Bill! Always challenging us to think critically, ask question, challenge our own assumptions, push farther. Bring a richness of practical experience and subject matter knowledge. Plus mad transferable skills- knowing how to manage a project well and apply tools to different contexts will likely be useful for MEMs no matter what their subject matter focus. Very applied with small projects every week to test tools out based on background readings and lectures, lots of discussions with classmates to workshop individual findings, great to be able to choose a project you're passionate about to focus on in a neat thought experiment to gain skills or helpful foundation for something you're actually going to do in the future.

This course is a really great at providing some skills for project design and management. I felt it was one of the most practical skills courses I took while at F&ES. Amy and Bill are great and their instruction was clear, enthusiastic, and comprehensive.
Amy and Bill have a wealth of knowledge to share. Highly recommend if you're thinking of going into wildlife conservation.
Practical applications.
Wonderful in-class discussions. Really engaging lecturer who helps you think through problems and challenges. Amazing class!

Building on material over trajectory of course; exposure to practical material; discussions of how material applies in real world context ; group discussions ; open environment for discussion facilitated by professors

Be able to use the tools in some sort of relevant wave was really awesome! I also loved that the class built on itself over time, and the final project was tying it all together! It was so much less stressful that way and made it a much more rewarding experience.
How professor Amy is responsible and careful to our projects

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I might add a bit more on how to select from among possible strategies- it was fun to make a case for what I thought were the most important in my final paper, but if there's a more systematic way to compare beyond best judgment based on situational analysis that would have been helpful to try out to be more confident I was going in the right direction on implementation.
It would be great to spend more on the activities portion of the project.
Perhaps more group work.

I think the only issue is that sometimes the readings are completely re-discussed in class which I don't think is necessary. It might more exciting and useful to actually practice the facilitation skills that are discussed in the early part of the course especially exploring stakeholder interests etc.
NA

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Again, perhaps more small group work.
Discussions helped encourage thinking around the lectures.
Great!

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course provided some much needed grounding in practice. So much of my work has been focused on learning theory, but this course was about design and completion of a project. That was very useful, especially as part of a professional degree.
This class is especially helpful if you already have some experience with conservation.
Thinking through these types of problems is applicable to any field of work. The processes and tools learned are incredibly useful (not just for conservation practitioners).

On the surface, this course doesn't seem to apply too much to what I've been doing in my coursework at FES, but at the same time, it's given me a framework to think about environment projects and how after leaving FES, you could actually carry out something from start to finish, and how you would measure your success. I've already discussed these projects multiple times in interviews, and it's always raise some eyebrows!
Very useful practical methods

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Amy and Bill are wonderful resources at F&ES. I wanted to learn from them about how to implement conservation programs while practicing some of these skills.
I sought ways to find practical ways to incorporate conservation into my future professional and personal endeavors, and for the opportunity to learn from Dr. Vedder and Dr. Webber.
To learn from experienced field practictioners about applied conservation tools and strategies that can help inform my future work

I took this course because I really like Bill and Amy and I think they bring interesting experiences practitioners to the table, and teach skills that they know to be useful in the professional workplace.
Would like to learn the conservation toolkit

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes! Very helpful to understand the broad range of tools conservation organizations use, the pros and cons, how I might tailor them to fit context-specific needs, what constraints and opportunities organizations face- I may not be working in conservation directly, but these are great transferable skills and really valuable knowledge from awesome people.
Yes!
Yes, you go through a lot of tools. Very helpful for anyone who will one day go to work for a conservation nonprofit.
Yes
Yes! Exceeded.
Yes
My experience in the course was well above my expectations. I really enjoyed thinking strategically about how to go about projects, and that something I would've gotten in any other course.
Yes!

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Shared feedback in small groups related to final project

I kind of wish our group criticism had been more guided and prompted with things perhaps with more time to actually review people's work. I think that would've been more useful than the more spontaneous look at someone's Concept map and give them feedback format.
NA

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Enjoy! Amy and Bill are fantastic and very willing to take time to mentor students on future plans, etc., so take time to get to know them outside of class as well. Think through what project you might want to focus on early on so you don't have to redo work as much after the fact as the semester progresses and you've applied tools to your initial case study- better not to have to backtrack with a new topic.
Have fun! When designing the project, do not leave the budget until the end! It will help to clarify your activities and to know what is realistic in your project area.
Completing the assignments can sometimes be rather straightforward and sometimes be very time consuming.
Take it!
Positive and open environment for dialogue facilitated by professors ; directly applicable material ; overall recommended if it fits your professional interests

Definitely don't fall behind. This course will be very enjoyable if you keep up and regularly meet with the professors and TA to judge your progress, and assess your approach. I saw people really struggle at the end because they hadn't worked at the right pace all semester. The more you do in the beginning and the more you iron out the issues you're having the more successful you will be towards the end. If you put in the work at the beginning the final paper will be much easier.
Please come and you will love it!
